newsitem.title: USA: Lilly to alter Humulin cartridge labels.
newsitem.headline: Lilly to alter Humulin cartridge labels.

text.p: Eli Lilly & Co said it will modify the package labels on future production runs of certain human insulin products under a court order.

Labeling for the drugmaker's Humulin cartridges for use in Novo Nordisk A/S insulin dispensing devices will be changed to show that Novo products described in the labels are registered trademarks, Lilly said.
The drugmaker was ordered to change the labels by Judge Barbara Jones in the U.S. District Court for Southern New York in a preliminary injunction responding to a lawsuit by Novo.
Novo said it alleged Lilly's cartridge packaging "confuses patients and healthcare professionals in violation of federal unfair competition law and was created in bad faith."

In response, Lilly said, "We think it is very unfortunate that Novo has used this trademark litigation to create concern among patients and healthcare professionals regarding the use of this important new treatment option."
No recall of any products is required, Lilly said.
Humulin is a form of human insulin for use by diabetics.
Lilly said it introduced Humulin catridges for use with dispensing devices made by Novo and Becton Dickinson and Co on July 19.
